subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Diploma in Transport Management
headline: This free online training course introduces transport management considerations in relation to rail and road in the UK.
description: This free online road transport management course outlines considerations of the management of rail and road networks in the UK. Start learning about the role of the transport manager in the road freight haulage sector and their legal responsibilities. Next, the course will analyze the role of the transport manager in passenger rail, from tender through to operation. This knowledge will help you to begin a career in transport management.
courseDescription:
Firstly, this course will evaluate the role of a transport manager who is working in the road haulage industry. You will learn the definitions of some of the common terms used in road freight haulage and find out about the legal responsibilities of the transport manager before looking at the regulations and licences required. You will also discover how bus services are operated in the UK.

Next, the course will outline the organisations involved, and the role that the transport operations manager plays in the passenger transport sector before exploring the legalities of operating an international coach service. Then, it examines the operation of the rail passenger industry and the franchise process. Furthermore, it will define the role of the transport manager in passenger rail and describe rail freight from tender through to operation and the stakeholders involved in the rail freight industry.

This free online course allows you to learn and study at your own pace, anywhere and at any time. Transport operations management is a fast-paced and constantly evolving industry. This course introduces you to transport management and offers insider knowledge of the industry and key terms used therein. So why wait? Start learning now and take one step closer to gaining a successful career in transport management.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Transport Management - Learning Outcomes

  • After successfully completing the following module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the definition,  purpose and key principles of transport management.
    • Describe the different sectors requiring transport management.
    • List the important personal attributes, skills and knowledge needed to be a transport manager.
    • Identify the challenges faced by the transport industry in the UK.
    • Explain how to forge a successful career in transport management. 

  • What is Transport Management?

  • Transport management is a multi-faceted sector including all types of transport: road, rail, sea and air and also passenger and freight transport.

    This course will explore the different aspects of transport management, their similarities and differences, the unique challenges presented by each one and what transport managers need to know about each.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • In 2015, 201 billion tonnes of freight was moved within the UK. Of this, 152 billion, or 76%, were moved by road. 31 billion, or 15%, were transported by water and 18 billion by rail. The main items moved by road were agricultural, forestry and raw materials (395 million tonnes), followed by 297 million tonnes of metal, mineral and chemical products and 284 million tonnes of food, beverages and tobacco.
  • Source: www.gov.uk Transport Statistics Great Britain 2016 Department for Transport.

  • The Roles of the Transport Manager

  • The day to day activities of a transport manager can be diverse, particularly as they are required to react to circumstances outside of their control, which can be rapidly changing.

    However, there are a number of daily tasks that they will need to undertake. These are likely to include:
    • Planning transport schedules and timetables, based on confirmed or estimated numbers or quantities of people or goods.
    • Managing costs and budgets, usually using analytical software, to help ensure the profitability of the business.
    • Resource management - ensuring that there are adequate staff and vehicles to meet demand.
    • Confirming that timetables and schedules are adhered to.
    • Ensuring that all relevant legislation is complied with. This will include the safety of both vehicles and people, emissions, weight and any customs liabilities.
    • Checking that all documentation is completed and recorded correctly.
    • Liaising with clients and suppliers, to ensure the most efficient service.

  • Challenges in the Transport Sector

  • The transport sector is facing a number of challenges at present. Transport managers must be aware of these, as they have a major impact currently and will continue to do so in the future.

    The main issues are sustainability, environmental impact and economy, infrastructure and overcrowding issues, safety, security and staffing problems. These will continue to be features for some time to come - and transport managers need to be aware of them and how they impact the industry.

    • Sustainability, Environmental Impact and Economy
    • Infrastructure

      Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua..
    • The transport industry is facing the tricky task of balancing the competing demands of sustainability, environmental impact and economy. Reducing environmental impact through reducing waste and cutting carbon dioxide emissions, whilst keeping costs constant, is a challenge, particularly when clients want better services without incurring an additional cost.

      In some areas, schemes are available to support operators in moving to greener, more efficient systems. One such scheme is the Fleet Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS), which assists fleet operators in assessing their performance and improving their practices. Manufacturers are responding to these issues, by making innovations to their vehicles that improve fuel efficiency and reduce carbon emissions.
      The transport industry is facing the tricky task of balancing the competing demands of sustainability, environmental impact and economy. Reducing environmental impact through reducing waste and cutting carbon dioxide emissions, whilst keeping costs constant, is a challenge, particularly when clients want better services without incurring an additional cost.

      In some areas, schemes are available to support operators in moving to greener, more efficient systems. One such scheme is the Fleet Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS), which assists fleet operators in assessing their performance and improving their practices. Manufacturers are responding to these issues, by making innovations to their vehicles that improve fuel efficiency and reduce carbon emissions.
    • Another set of challenges relate to infrastructure limitations, particularly in the UK. Populations are rising, meaning that people are making more journeys than ever before and there is more demand for goods than ever before. This means that roads, rail, seas and skies are ever more overcrowded, which is affecting the ability to move goods and people in an efficient and timely manner, leading to increased costs.

      The government is seeking to modernise the country’s infrastructure, both through the modernisation of existing routes, such as the M1, M4 and M5 and through the construction of brand new projects, such as HS2. However, these projects take many years to complete and transport managers must continue to manage this challenge for the foreseeable future.

However, these projects take many years to complete and transport managers must continue to manage this challenge for the foreseeable future.

      Another set of challenges relate to infrastructure limitations, particularly in the UK. Populations are rising, meaning that people are making more journeys than ever before and there is more demand for goods than ever before. This means that roads, rail, seas and skies are ever more overcrowded, which is affecting the ability to move goods and people in an efficient and timely manner, leading to increased costs.

      The government is seeking to modernise the country’s infrastructure, both through the modernisation of existing routes, such as the M1, M4 and M5 and through the construction of brand new projects, such as HS2. However, these projects take many years to complete and transport managers must continue to manage this challenge for the foreseeable future.

  • Challenges in the Transport Sector

  • The transport sector is facing a number of challenges at present. Transport managers must be aware of these, as they have a major impact currently and will continue to do so in the future.

    The main issues are sustainability, environmental impact and economy, infrastructure and overcrowding issues, safety, security and staffing problems. These will continue to be features for some time to come - and transport managers need to be aware of them and how they impact the industry.

    • The transport industry is facing the tricky task of balancing the competing demands of sustainability, environmental impact and economy. Reducing environmental impact through reducing waste and cutting carbon dioxide emissions, whilst keeping costs constant, is a challenge, particularly when clients want better services without incurring an additional cost.

      In some areas, schemes are available to support operators in moving to greener, more efficient systems. One such scheme is the Fleet Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS), which assists fleet operators in assessing their performance and improving their practices. Manufacturers are responding to these issues, by making innovations to their vehicles that improve fuel efficiency and reduce carbon emissions.

  • Introduction to Transport Management - Lesson Summary

    • Transport is a key part of modern life. It is vital to national and international economies and people’s daily lives. 
    • For those who want to work in the sector, there is a wide range of opportunities in a whole raft of sectors, from public and private passenger transport, through to international freight shipping. Different industries have different requirements, but the basics remain the same.
    • Successful transport managers need to have a wide range of skills. These include strong organisational capabilities, attention to detail, commercial awareness, excellent time management skills, ability to communicate effectively and the capacity to maintain knowledge of current and changing regulations. 
    • As well as attention to detail, transport managers need to be able to take an overview of situations and have the confidence to make changes, even where there may be questions.
    • The transport industry is facing a range of challenges. These include tightening regulations relating to sustainability and environmental impact, infrastructure issues, safety legislation, security concerns and a shortage of suitable staff.
    • For those seeking to enter the industry, there is a range of routes. Some people work in related fields before becoming a transport manager, whilst others take a more formal route through higher education and professional qualifications.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the road infrastructure in the UK, the types of roads and their usage.
    • Describe the organisations that manage the British road infrastructure.
    • List the challenges presented by the current infrastructure and strategies to combat them.
    • Identify the rail infrastructure and the bodies involved in its operation and management.
    • Explain the challenges currently faced by the rail industry and planned projects.

  • Types of Transport Infrastructure

  • The UK’s transport infrastructure is comprised of rail, road, airports, inland waterways and ports and is used by both passengers and freight.

    The organisation of each of these transport modes is complicated, involving numerous stakeholders and each presents challenges as the UK moves forward.

    This module will look at the road and rail infrastructures, the different bodies responsible for their operation and how the issues currently faced by those who utilise them are being dealt with.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Road freight contributes £11.2 billion to the UK economy. In 2014, the 36,552 road freight companies in the sector employed 222,000 people in total. 151 billion tonne-kilometres were transported.

    Source: www.gov.uk Road Use Statistics: 2016.
